variant.question: As a cause of accidents, the human factor

options.text: is cited in approximately 70 % – 80 % of aviation accidents.
has increased considerably since 1980 – the percentage of accident in which this factor has been involved has more than tripled since this date.
plays a negligible role in commercial aviation accidents. It is much more important in general aviation.
which is cited in current statistics applies to flight crew and ATC only.

variant.question: Which of the following concepts relating to human reliability is true?

options.text: If equipment is designed in such a way that it can be operated wrongly, then sooner or later, it will be.
Response to a particular stressful influence does not vary from one person to another.
Expectation has no influence on perception.
Performance is totally independent of motivation.

variant.question: Improvement of human reliability should entail:

options.text: an effort to understand the causes and find means of recovery for errors committed.
the analysis of modes of human failures.
in aviation, the elimination of errors on the part of front-line operators.
the elimination of latent errors before they can effect performance.

variant.question: Thinking on human reliability is changing.

options.text: Human errors are now considered as being inevitable.
Human errors can be avoided. All it takes is to be vigilant and to extend one’s knowledge.
The individual view of safety has gradually replaced the systemic view of safety.
It is thought that it will be possible to eliminate errors in the near future.

variant.question:
Which of the factors below can have a negative impact on human reliability?
1. Complacency 
 2. Distractions 
 3. Fatigue 
 4. Low and medium workload levels 
 5. Lack of awareness

Which of the following items are factors that contribute to human error? 
1 Personality
2 Motivation and attitudes
3 Emotional state 
4 Standard operating procedures.

options.text: 1 and 2 only
2 and 3 only

variant.question:
The causes of human error can be abundant and complex
Which of the following factors could contribute to human error? 
1) Personality. 
2) Motivation and attitudes. 
3) Emotional state. 
4) External environmental factors.
Which of the following lists all the correct answers?

The causes of human error can be abundant and complex. Which of the following factors could contribute to human error? - Personality - Motivation and attitudes - Emotional state - External environmental factors - Standard operating procedures (SOPs) Which of the following lists all the correct answers?
